intro: Lipocarpha isolepis, commonly known as the narrow-leaved marsh grass, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to wetland environments in tropical and subtropical regions. It belongs to the Poaceae family, which includes grasses, and is characterized by its slender, cylindrical stems and narrow, grass-like leaves. The plant typically grows in shallow water or moist soil, often forming dense colonies in marshes and swampy areas. Its small, inconspicuous flowers are arranged in spikelets, and it plays a role in stabilizing wetland ecosystems. Lipocarpha isolepis is adapted to fluctuating water levels and is an important component of aquatic plant communities.
